main.docTitle: Notaries Public (Grounds for Refusal to Issue Practising Certificate) Rules

section.name: s2
section.heading: Grounds for refusal to issue practising certificate

subsection.leadIn: The grounds on which the Society of Notaries may refuse to issue a practising certificate to an applicant are the following—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: that the application does not comply with section 2 of the Notaries Public (Practising Certificate) Rules (Cap. 159, sub. leg. AG);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: that in the opinion of the Society, the applicant—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: has conducted himself in a manner that is unbecoming of a notary public; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: is unfit to practise as a notary public.

subsection.leadIn: Without limiting the generality of subsection (1)(b), an applicant may be regarded as having conducted himself in a manner that is unbecoming of a notary public or as being unfit to practise as a notary public if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the applicant has been suspended from practising either as a notary public or as a solicitor;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the applicant is entitled to practise the law of a foreign jurisdiction, but he has been suspended from so practising;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the applicant has been convicted in Hong Kong or elsewhere of an offence involving fraud, dishonesty or moral turpitude;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: the applicant has knowingly provided to the Society of Notaries false or misleading information in relation to the application; or

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: the applicant suffers or appears to suffer from a mental disorder within the meaning of the Mental Health Ordinance (Cap. 136).
